text:
USER: Ign:7 https://apt.datadoghq.com stable InRelease                               
Hit:8 https://download.docker.com/linux/debian trixie InRelease                
Hit:9 https://packages.microsoft.com/debian/13/prod trixie InRelease           
Hit:10 https://apt.datadoghq.com stable Release                                
Hit:12 https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/code stable InRelease              
Get:13 https://cli.github.com/packages stable InRelease [3,917 B]              
Hit:14 https://repo.radeon.com/rocm/apt/7.1.1 noble InRelease                  
Get:15 https://pkgs.tailscale.com/stable/debian trixie InRelease    
Hit:16 http://deb.debian.org/debian trixie-backports InRelease                 
Hit:17 https://repo.radeon.com/graphics/7.1.1/ubuntu noble InRelease           
Fetched 151 kB in 1s (190 kB/s)                                  
All packages are up to date.    
Error: Unable to locate package openmediavault
(base) thewolfwalksalone@csmcloud-server:~$ sudo omv-confdbadm populate
sudo: omv-confdbadm: command not found
(base) thewolfwalksalone@csmcloud-server:~$ 


ASSISTANT: [THINKING]
The user tried to install OpenMediaVault but the package wasn't found. Looking at the error, it seems the OMV repository wasn't added properly or OMV doesn't support Debian 13 (trixie) yet.

Let me check - Debian 13 "trixie" is very new (currently testing/unstable). OpenMediaVault typically lags behind Debian releases. The repository I suggested was for "sandworm" which is OMV 7 for Debian 12 (bookworm).

OMV might not have a release for Debian 13 yet. Let me suggest alternatives:

1. Just use plain NFS (no web UI) - simpler, works now
2. Use Cockpit with cockpit-navigator for web-based file management
3. Wait for OMV to support Debian 13
4. Downgrade to Debian 12 (bad idea)

I should recommend using plain NFS server setup since that will work immediately and the user can manage shares via command line or write a simple web interface if needed.
